channel.title: World & Nation
channel.description: Nation and World articles from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: An Oregon tribe's casino bid sparks furor over what land tribes can rightfully call home
item.dc:creator: Hannah Wiley
item.description: The Coquille tribe wants to build a casino on the California border. Pushback from nearby tribes raises a question: Who gets to determine a tribe's rightful homeland?
item.content:encoded: The Coquille tribe wants to build a casino on the California border. Pushback from nearby tribes raises a question: Who gets to determine a tribe's rightful homeland?

media:content.media:title: 1411694-me-casino-battle-norcal-12-brv.jpg
media:content.media:description: Yreka, CA - February 06: Northern California Karuk Tribal chairman Russell 'Buster' Attebery at the tribe's Rain Rock Casino, on Tuesday, Feb. 6, 2024 in Yreka, CA. There's a big battle brewing with the Coquille Indian Tribe's proposed Cedars at Bear Creek casino, with the Karuk tribe contending it will eat into their own revenues and once again put tribes in competition with one another (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. Times Executive Editor Terry Tang solidifies leadership position
item.dc:creator: Meg James
item.description: Since being tapped as interim executive editor, Tang moved rapidly to reorganize the newsroom, form her own leadership team and put a heavier emphasis on traditional news gathering.
item.content:encoded: Since being tapped as interim executive editor, Tang moved rapidly to reorganize the newsroom, form her own leadership team and put a heavier emphasis on traditional news gathering.

item.title: Democrats book $27 million in ads in California congressional races
item.dc:creator: Seema Mehta
item.description: The ad buy includes more than $19 million in L.A., a media market where some hotly contested congressional races could determine control of the House.
item.content:encoded: The ad buy includes more than $19 million in L.A., a media market where some hotly contested congressional races could determine control of the House.

item.title: How an L.A. humanitarian group is using soccer to help children stuck at Mexico border
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: An L.A.-based nonprofit with support from Angel City FC is using soccer to help children stranded on the U.S.-Mexico border cope with waiting for asylum.
item.content:encoded: An L.A.-based nonprofit with support from Angel City FC is using soccer to help children stranded on the U.S.-Mexico border cope with waiting for asylum.

media:content.media:title: soccer11.jpg
media:content.media:description: Children play soccer at the Sidewalk School in Matamoros, Mexico.

item.title: Cost of work visas surges, upping the ante for multitude of California's small businesses
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo, Don Lee
item.description: Experts said the visa fee hikes could make a difference in some employers' efforts to recruit foreign workers.
item.content:encoded: Experts said the visa fee hikes could make a difference in some employers' efforts to recruit foreign workers.

media:content.media:title: 1432038-me-immigrant-worker-visa-fees-increase-06-ajs.jpg
media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - April 05: Ally Bolour, an immigration attorney, photographed at his Bolour/Carl Immigration Group office in Los Angeles Friday, April 5, 2024. Bolour's clients, many of them entertainment industry companies looking to hire foreign actors and other artists for film shoots, must pay more for filings in the wake of the U.S. government's sweeping visa fee increases that took effect on Monday. He says the extra visa expenses already have made some clients delay planned expansions to the U.S. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: It's not just RFK Jr.: Biden faces serious danger from third-party candidates
item.dc:creator: Doyle McManus
item.description: Biden isn't running only against Trump. An anti-vax Kennedy and other third-party candidates could draw enough Democratic defectors to swing the election.
item.content:encoded: Biden isn't running only against Trump. An anti-vax Kennedy and other third-party candidates could draw enough Democratic defectors to swing the election.

media:content.media:title: 1426446-me-0330-rfk-cesar-chavez-gem-001.jpg
media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 30, 2024 - - Independent Presidential Candidate Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., against a mural of images of him as a young man, hosts Cesar Chavez Day to celebrate the life and legacy of Cesar Chavez at the iconic Old Ticket Concourse at Union Station in Los Angeles on March 30, 2024. This event, on Chavez's birthday holiday weekend, included remarks by Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., music by the all-female mariachi group Las Colibri and remarks from Bishop Juan Carlos Mendez. Kennedy Jr. has used Cesar Chavez's name and image in his campaign for president, eliciting outrage from Chavez family members. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: RFK Jr. speaks candidly about his gravelly voice: 'If I could sound better, I would'
item.dc:creator: James Rainey
item.description: 'If I could sound better, I would,' says the presidential candidate, who has spasmodic dysphonia, a neurological condition that affects his vocal cords.
item.content:encoded: 'If I could sound better, I would,' says the presidential candidate, who has spasmodic dysphonia, a neurological condition that affects his vocal cords.

media:content.media:title: 1405450-me-0201-black-history-month-kennedy-023.jpg
media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - FEBRUARY 1, 2024 - - Independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., participates in, "The Present State of Black America," panel discussion for the start of Black History Month at Artlounge Collective in Los Angeles on February 1, 2024. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Raids, fines and digging through underwear drawers: Korean president's war on 'fake news'
item.dc:creator: Max Kim
item.description: South Korea's president has made combating disinformation a centerpiece of his agenda. But free press advocates say his vow to keep reporters honest is a pretext to intimidate his critics
item.content:encoded: South Korea's president has made combating disinformation a centerpiece of his agenda. But free press advocates say his vow to keep reporters honest is a pretext to intimidate his critics

item.title: This epic slice of Arizona feeds their souls but lacks a basic necessity: Water
item.dc:creator: Tyrone Beason
item.description: More than a third of the Navajo Nation lacks running water. As the tribe nears a pact with Arizona over water rights, a California nonprofit looks to help.
item.content:encoded: More than a third of the Navajo Nation lacks running water. As the tribe nears a pact with Arizona over water rights, a California nonprofit looks to help.

media:content.media:title: 1384223-me-navajo-water-dig-deep-10-brv.jpg
media:content.media:description: Oljato-Monument Valley, UT - December 12: A bird takes flight over Monument Valley in the Navajo Nation on Tuesday, Dec. 12, 2023 in Oljato-Monument Valley, UT. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: These scientists think an 'awe'-some eclipse could help unite Americans in troubled times
item.dc:creator: Karen Kaplan
item.description: Awe is a serious topic among psychologists, including one at UC Irvine investigating whether awe-inspiring solar eclipses can help unite Americans.
item.content:encoded: Awe is a serious topic among psychologists, including one at UC Irvine investigating whether awe-inspiring solar eclipses can help unite Americans.

media:content.media:title: 2955138_SCI_0821_ECLIPSE_MWY_0628.JPG
media:content.media:description: SALEM, ORE. -- MONDAY, AUGUST 21, 2017: In-camera multiple exposure of the solar eclipse as seen in Salem, Ore., on Aug. 21, 2017. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A total eclipse is more than a spectacle. So I'm on the road to see it â again
item.dc:creator: John Penner
item.description: Why would someone journey across the country to watch a total eclipse? Because it's more than just an astronomical rarity: It may be the best show in the universe.
item.content:encoded: Why would someone journey across the country to watch a total eclipse? Because it's more than just an astronomical rarity: It may be the best show in the universe.

item.title: Why this year's average California snowpack is no reason for celebration
item.dc:creator: Ned Kleiner
item.description: The relationship between snowfall and climate change is not as simple as it might first appear.
item.content:encoded: The relationship between snowfall and climate change is not as simple as it might first appear.

item.title: Granderson: Netanyahu owes the U.S. better answers about Gaza
item.dc:creator: LZ Granderson
item.description: Americans are supplying the weapons that enable Israel's war. In exchange, Israel should show that it is pursuing peace.
item.content:encoded: Americans are supplying the weapons that enable Israel's war. In exchange, Israel should show that it is pursuing peace.

item.title: Rare magnitude 4.8 earthquake rattles New Jersey and New York, is felt across Northeast
item.dc:creator: Jenny Jarvie, Rong-Gong Lin II, Laura King
item.description: There were no reports of damage or injuries from a magnitude 4.8 quake felt Friday morning across New Jersey, New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania.
item.content:encoded: There were no reports of damage or injuries from a magnitude 4.8 quake felt Friday morning across New Jersey, New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania.

item.title: What is Israel's track record on investigating civilian deaths?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Wilkinson
item.description: Israel's killing of World Central Kitchen aid workers in Gaza is the latest example of an incident provoking outrage but potentially little deep change.
item.content:encoded: Israel's killing of World Central Kitchen aid workers in Gaza is the latest example of an incident provoking outrage but potentially little deep change.

item.title: Column: Antiabortion agitators are trying to cripple a lifesaving federal healthcare law
item.dc:creator: Michael Hiltzik
item.description: Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act mandates that emergency rooms treat all arriving patients. The antiabortion crowd wants to exempt emergency abortions. The Supreme Court is giving them a hearing
item.content:encoded: Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act mandates that emergency rooms treat all arriving patients. The antiabortion crowd wants to exempt emergency abortions. The Supreme Court is giving them a hearing

item.title: Column: Why many Latinos are calling for a cease-fire in Gaza
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano
item.description: Latinos who have never been politically active are now attending rallies expressing support for Palestinians.
item.content:encoded: Latinos who have never been politically active are now attending rallies expressing support for Palestinians.

media:content.media:title: watermelon-viva-paletine
media:content.media:description: Activists rally outside El Monte City Hall on Tuesday, April 2 before the El Monte city Council meeting. The council unanimously passed a resolution asking for a permanent cease-fire in Gaza, becoming the seventh Latino majority city in Southern California to do so.

item.title: Trump appears at a fundraiser for a creator of his 'family separation' policy
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Family separation was one of the most controversial Trump immigration policies. He attended a fundraiser for a nonprofit led by a creator of the policy.
item.content:encoded: Family separation was one of the most controversial Trump immigration policies. He attended a fundraiser for a nonprofit led by a creator of the policy.

item.title: Biden and Trump's main challenge? The apathetic voters who could decide the election

item.description: The Biden-Trump rematch. The early primary season wrap-up. The 'double-haters.' Why apathy is a common sentiment among voters.
item.content:encoded: The Biden-Trump rematch. The early primary season wrap-up. The 'double-haters.' Why apathy is a common sentiment among voters.

item.title: Prosecutors put men on death row. This California D.A. wants to take them off
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: After a trip to Alabama that helped him see the connection between slavery and the death penalty, Santa Clara County Dist. Atty. Jeff Rosen is working to call back the death sentences of 15 men convicted from his county.
item.content:encoded: After a trip to Alabama that helped him see the connection between slavery and the death penalty, Santa Clara County Dist. Atty. Jeff Rosen is working to call back the death sentences of 15 men convicted from his county.

media:content.media:title: 1424123-me-0325-death-row-rcg-7896.jpg
media:content.media:description: San Quentin, CA, Monday, March 25, 2024 - San Quentin Rehabilitation Center. California is shutting down San Quentin's death row and transferring 471 condemned people out of the prison and into the general population at other prisons throughout the state. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Trump says he'll jail his opponents. Members of the House Jan. 6 committee are preparing
item.dc:creator: Sarah D. Wire
item.description: California Democratic Reps. Zoe Lofgren, Adam B. Schiff and Pete Aguilar are among those who believe they could be targeted for retribution if Trump is reelected.
item.content:encoded: California Democratic Reps. Zoe Lofgren, Adam B. Schiff and Pete Aguilar are among those who believe they could be targeted for retribution if Trump is reelected.

media:content.media:title: 971104-na-pol-0609-jan6-hearing-kkn-0074.jpg
media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - JUNE 09: Rep. Pete Aguilar (D-Redlands), Rep. Adam B. Schiff (D-Burbank),and Rep. Zoe Lofgren (D-San Jose) during a House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th hearing in the Cannon House Office Building on Thursday, June 9, 2022 in Washington, DC. The bipartisan Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack On the United States Capitol has spent nearly a year conducting more than 1,000 interviews, reviewed more than 140,000 documents day of the attack. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: News Analysis: Netanyahu faces massive protests in Israel. Could the war in Gaza be his undoing?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Wilkinson, Marcus Yam
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu is the king of political survival. But amid the Gaza war, the opposition comes from diverse segments of Israeli society and from abroad.
item.content:encoded: Benjamin Netanyahu is the king of political survival. But amid the Gaza war, the opposition comes from diverse segments of Israeli society and from abroad.

media:content.media:title: 1358911-fg-0402-israelgazawar-mwy-105739.jpg
media:content.media:description: JERUSALEM, ISRAEL -- APRIL 2, 2024: Protesters holding flags, banners and lit candles march through central Jerusalem, Israel, Tuesday, April 2, 2024. Thousands of demonstrators surged through Jerusalem demanding that the government reach a cease-fire deal to free the remaining hostages held in Gaza by Hamas militants, hold early national elections and argued in favor for all draft-aged religious ultra orthodox to join the military. (MARCUS YAM / LOS ANGELES TIMES)
media:content.media:credit: Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times

item.title: News Analysis: Supreme Court has right and far-right wings. Their justices might not be those you'd guess
item.dc:creator: David Lauter
item.description: The abortion pill case shows the gap between the Supreme Court's far-right and merely conservative justices. A second Trump presidency could move the bench further right.
item.content:encoded: The abortion pill case shows the gap between the Supreme Court's far-right and merely conservative justices. A second Trump presidency could move the bench further right.

item.title: Los Angeles couple's Supreme Court case sheds light on immigrant visa rejections
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: Luis Acensio Cordero was denied a visa to return to the U.S. from El Salvador and has been separated from his wife, Sandra MuÃ±oz, since 2015.
item.content:encoded: Luis Acensio Cordero was denied a visa to return to the U.S. from El Salvador and has been separated from his wife, Sandra MuÃ±oz, since 2015.

media:content.media:title: 1394064-na-pol-gang-tattoos-supreme-court-06-fo.jpg
media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - July 13: Portrait of Sandra Munoz, a celebrated civil rights attorney in Los Angeles. She is holding a photo of her husband Luis on January 3, 2024, in Los Angeles, CA. They have been separated since 2015. Luis, who was undocumented, applied for a waiver of his illegal entry to seek citizenship after they got married. The final step was considered a formality -- he would go back to El Salvador for an interview at the U.S. consulate there and fly back to the U.S. once it was approved. Instead, it was denied. When their lawyers pressed the government for why, the State Department admitted that his tattoos -- of La Virgen de Guadalupe, a tribal design and theatrical masks -- were among the reasons they had found him to be an MS-13 gang member, an assertion he vehemently denies. Last year, the 9th Circuit sided with the couple, but the Biden administration appealed to the Supreme Court. The high court is expected to decide next month whether to take up the case, which would have ripple effects for any immigrant seeking to challenge the government's views of their character. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hay grown for cattle consumes nearly half the water drawn from Colorado River, study finds
item.dc:creator: Ian James
item.description: Much of the Colorado River's water is used for agriculture. A new study shows 46% of the water that is diverted is used to grow hay to feed cattle.
item.content:encoded: Much of the Colorado River's water is used for agriculture. A new study shows 46% of the water that is diverted is used to grow hay to feed cattle.

media:content.media:title: 835490-me-palo-verde-farm-water-deal009_LS.jpg
media:content.media:description: BLYTHE, CALIF. - SEP 7, 2021. Colorado River water irrigates a farm field in Blythe. The Metropolitan Water District is working with local growers lto leave some of their fields fallow in exchange for cash payments. The desert agricultural industry in Blythe draws water from the nearby Colorado River, and the goal is for farmers to use less river water and allow unused supplies to serve the needs of people in urban areas downstream. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Another casualty of escalating clashes in the West Bank: the Palestinian olive harvest
item.dc:creator: Nabih Bulos
item.description: As Israeli settlers use the war in Gaza as a pretext for a land grab in Palestinians' other territory, olive farmers fear their way of life may be on the verge of extinction.
item.content:encoded: As Israeli settlers use the war in Gaza as a pretext for a land grab in Palestinians' other territory, olive farmers fear their way of life may be on the verge of extinction.

media:content.media:title: 1358911-fg-0202-israelgazawar-mwy-47404.jpg
media:content.media:description: TURMUS AYYA, OCCUPIED WEST BANK -- DECEMBER 1, 2023: Amal Abu Awad, 59, harvests olives by hand on their family groves next to their home in Turmus Ayya, Occupied West Bank, Friday, Dec. 1, 2023. Since the start of the Israel-Hamas war in October, olive farmers throughout the region worry that their way of life may be on the verge of extinction N with settlers using the war as a pretext for a land grab. Abu Awad and his family have been beaten up and repeatedly threatened with expulsion from their land. Their house was vandalized, and some of their farm equipment was confiscated or destroyed. But even before the war, the annual job had become increasingly difficult over the years for the more than 100,000 Palestinian families in the West Bank that rely on it for their livelihood. (MARCUS YAM / LOS ANGELES TIMES)
media:content.media:credit: Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times

item.title: What the Supreme Court's abortion pill case could mean for California
item.dc:creator: Sonja Sharp
item.description: The high court is weighing a case that could rewrite the rules of care in more than two-thirds of U.S. abortions, limiting access to a popular drug even in states where it remains legal.
item.content:encoded: The high court is weighing a case that could rewrite the rules of care in more than two-thirds of U.S. abortions, limiting access to a popular drug even in states where it remains legal.

item.title: Starvation has decimated gray whales off the Pacific Coast. Can the giants ever recover?
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Researchers suspect that starvation may have killed half off all gray whales off the Pacific Coast of North America. What happened to their food source?
item.content:encoded: Researchers suspect that starvation may have killed half off all gray whales off the Pacific Coast of North America. What happened to their food source?

media:content.media:title: 768971-ME-whales-dead-san-francisco-04-CMC.jpg
media:content.media:description: Muir Beach, San Francisco, California-May 6, 2021-Three more gray whales have washed ashore in the San Francisco Bay Area, adding to the four that washed up in April of this year. Visitors to Muir Beach look at a decomposing gray whale as they enjoy the beach on April 17, 2021. PHOTO TAKEN ON APRIL 17, 2021. (Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: For some in Israel, a wartime holiday strikes a discordant note
item.dc:creator: Laura King
item.description: The Jewish holiday of Purim is normally lighthearted and festive, but against a backdrop of war, some celebrations take on a stridently nationalistic edge.
item.content:encoded: The Jewish holiday of Purim is normally lighthearted and festive, but against a backdrop of war, some celebrations take on a stridently nationalistic edge.

media:content.media:title: 1358911-fg-0325-israelgazawar-mwy-100102.jpg
media:content.media:description: JERUSALEM, ISRAEL -- MARCH 25, 2024: Ultra orthodox men stop traffic as IsraelOs religious communities celebrate the Purim holiday by donning costumes, drinking alcohol, singing and dancing after traditional reading religious scriptures, in the Mea Shearim neighborhood Jerusalem, Israel, Monday, March 25, 2024. IsraelOs celebrations this year of the joyous holiday of Purim, based on a biblical account of Jewish salvation, presented a jarring juxtaposition with the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 32,000 Palestinians as Israel seeks to destroy the militant group Hamas. (MARCUS YAM / LOS ANGELES TIMES)
media:content.media:credit: Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Biden, at risk with young voters, is racing to shift marijuana policy

media:content.media:title: ap22092497074876.jpg
media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 2, 2016 file photo, a demonstrator waves a flag with marijuana leaves on it during a protest calling for the legalization of marijuana, outside of the White House in Washington. Marijuana would be decriminalized at the federal level under legislation the House approved Friday as Democrats made the case for allowing states to set their own policies on pot. ( AP Photo/Jose Luis Magana)

item.title: At a boy's funeral, a Palestinian village gathers to bid farewell
item.dc:creator: Marcus Yam
item.description: A visual essay on the daily lives of sorrow and grief for Palestinians living in the West Bank.
item.content:encoded: A visual essay on the daily lives of sorrow and grief for Palestinians living in the West Bank.

media:content.media:title: 1358911-fg-0305-israelgazawar-mwy-86119.jpg
media:content.media:description: BURIN, OCCUPIED WEST BANK -- MARCH 5, 2024: Salam Najjar bids farewell to her son Amro Najjar, 10, during a funeral in Burin, Occupied West Bank , Tuesday, March 5, 2024. According to his father, Mohammad Najjar, Israeli forces opened fire on their vehicle after they encountered the Israeli military incursion into the Palestinian village and one of the bullets hit Amro directly in the head, killing him. Since the Hamas attack on Oct. 7th and IsraelOs full-scale military offensive in the Gaza Strip, 106 Palestinian children have been killed in the occupied West Bank according to the Defense for Children International Palestine (DCIP). (MARCUS YAM / LOS ANGELES TIMES)
media:content.media:credit: Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times

item.title: This mega-city is running out of water. What will 22 million people do when the taps run dry?

media:content.media:title: travel-frida-and-diego-82876-1.jpg
media:content.media:description: In this photo taken on Sept. 5, 2017, a little-known mural by Diego Rivera, "Water, the Source of Life," is seen inside a monument to Mexico City's water system called the Carcamo de Dolores, or the Dolores Sump. Originally painted to be viewed underwater, the pool was drained when it became clear that the work would slowly be ruined. The hydraulic structure is located inside the Second Section of the Mexican capital's Chapultepec Park. (AP Photo/Anita Snow)
